
## Bar Plots
Bar plots can be build with **matplotlib's** **pyplot** library.
To contstruct a bar plot using **matplotlib**, first import **matplotlib**. If using a Jupyter notebook, include the line ```%matplotlib inline```
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In&nbsp;[1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="c1">#if using a Jupyter notebook, include</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
To create a bar chart with **matplotlib**, we need some data. Our data set comes from a set of tensile test measurements to determine a material's tensile strength. Tensile strength is a material property that indicates the maximum amount of stress a material can endure before fracture.  Different materials have different tensile strengths. Materials with higher tensile strength are generally considered stronger than materials with low tensile strength. 

The tensile strength of three different metals shown below:

 * Brass = 125 MPa
 * Aluminum = 276 MPa
 * Steel = 655 MPa

To build a bar chart, first we create a list of the names of the materials and a list of tensile strengths. Then we need a list of bar positions. This seems sort of strange, but the ```plt.bar()``` method needs to know where along the x-axis to put the bars. The ```ax.bar()``` method requires two positional arguments:

```python
plt.bar([list of bar positions], [list of bar heights])
```

An error results if only a list of bar heights is specified.
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In&nbsp;[2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">materials</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;Brass&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Aluminum&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Steel&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">heights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">125</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">276</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">655</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">x_pos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
Next, build the plot by passing in the list of bar position ```x_pos``` and list of bar heights ```heights``` as positional arguments to the ```plt.bar()``` function. These positional arguments (```x_pos```,```heights```) must be in the correct order.
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In&nbsp;[3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_pos</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">heights</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
Details are added to the bar plot by specifying the bar labels and where to put those labels. A change in alpha value (opacity) makes the slightly transparent.  Besides changing opacity, a number of other keyword arguments can included in ```plt.bar()``` function call. A few of the ```plt.bar()``` keyword arguments are shown in the table below:

| bar plot feature | keyword argument | Example |
| --- | --- | --- |
| bar face color | ```color=``` | ```plt.bar(x_pos, heights, color='g')``` |
| bar outline color  | ```edgecolor=``` | ```plt.edgecolor(x_pos, heights, edgecolor='k')``` |
| bar outline width | ```linewidth=``` | ```plt.bar(x_pos, heights, linewidth=3)``` |
| y-error bar heights  | ```yerr=``` | ```plt.bar(x_pos, heights, yerr=[0.1, 0.3, 0.2])``` |
| error bar cap width | ```capsize=``` | ```plt.bar(x_pos, heights, capsize=5)``` |


Assuming ```x_pos``` is a list of x-positions for the bars, and ```heights``` is a list of bar heights, an example ```plt.bar()``` function call is:

```python
plt.bar(x_pos, heights,
        color='b',
        edgecolor='k',
        linewidth=4,
        yerr=[0.1, 0.3, 0.1],
        capsize=5)
```

Labels can be added to the bar plot with the same **matplotlib** functions used to customize line plots. These include:

 * ```plt.xlabel('y-axis label')```
 * ```plt.ylabel('x-axis label')```
 * ```plt.title('Title')```
 * ```plt.xticks([positions], [labels])```
 * ```plt.grid(axis='y')```
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In&nbsp;[4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>\
<span class="c1"># if using a Jupyter notebook, include</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline

<span class="n">materials</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;Brass&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Aluminum&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">&#39;Steel&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">heights</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">125</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">276</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">655</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">x_pos</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_pos</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">heights</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Tensile Strength (MPa)&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Metals&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xticks</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">materials</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">grid</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">&#39;y&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Tensile Strength of 3 Metals&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>
